floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull

items.message: This flood alert has been removed as river levels have fallen. No significant rainfall is expected in the next couple of days. We are continuing to monitor the forecast and will re-issue this alert if required.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but are gradually falling on the River Churn as a result of previous heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Cerney Wick area. The weather forecast today, 29/11/23 and into tomorrow is dry. We expect river levels to continue to fall slowly over the next few days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 30/11/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: River levels are steady but remain high on the Upper River Derwent around Low Marishes and are expected to remain high on Thursday 30/11/2023. River levels elsewhere on the Upper River Derwent are currently steady or falling. No further significant rainfall is forecast over the coming days but river levels will fall slowly. We continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5pm on 30/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and its small tributaries from Calcutt to Lechlade

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Blunsdon Brook, Water Eaton Brook, Marston Meysey Brook, Share Ditch, Bydemill Brook, Westrop Brook, Downington Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high but are falling slowly along the River Thames and small tributaries as a result of previous heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible. The weather forecast today, 29/11/23 and into tomorrow is dry. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 30/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from now, Thursday 30th November, and for the next few days. Water levels continue to remain high in this area.  This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning.  The recent series of high spring tides has now peaked, and will fall away over the next few days, allowing the freshwater river flows to drain out to sea at low tide as normal again. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Friday 1st December, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Holderness Drain, Barmston Drain

items.message: River levels remain high on Frodingham Beck, River Hull and Roam Drain and areas around Wilfholme due to recent rainfall. No further significant rainfall is forecast over the coming days. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5pm on 30/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible, especially in the Chalgrove area. The weather forecast today, 29/11/23 and into tomorrow is dry. floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force as river levels are stable but remain high around Elvington and Thornton Lock on Bielby Beck due to recent rainfall. River levels are steady at Elvington. Levels on Bielby Beck are continuing to fall. No further significant rainfall is forecast over the coming days but river levels will fall slowly. We continue to closely monitor the forecast. Please monitor local weather and river conditions and avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 5pm on 30/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels are high but steady on the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon due to raised groundwater levels.
Areas most at risk include tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.
Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon.
No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 29/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady on the River Piddle.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Piddle, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.
Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon.
River levels are expected to remain high.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 29/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Tern - Walcot river gauge. Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.   
No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high throughout today.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences .  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  by 10:00am on 30/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to rainfall over the past few weeks and remain high at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming weeks. 

Levels are high but slowly falling in response to dry conditions over the past week, but levels remain responsive to further rainfall. Further rainfall is expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain. Groundwater levels will continue to remain high and may still impact low lying gardens and cellars. 

Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 01/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River East Glen, River West Glen, River Tham

items.message: The risk of flooding from rivers in the East and West Glen catchments has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 7.56 m and is generally falling slowly. The drain level is 7.21 m and continues to fall slowly.
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.30 m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86 m, and the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93 m. 

The forecast is largely dry today, Wednesday 29/11/2023. Thursday may bring some rain, sleet and possible snow on the hills. The River Yeo is generally falling slowly and occasionally fluctuates in response to pumping changes elsewhere in the river system. We continue to pump as much as possible to evacuate water from the Moors.

The situation is being monitored and staff are checking the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on local road closures.
For water levels on the rivers, please refer to our website: (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels).

This message will be updated by 15:00 on Thursday 30/11/2023.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60 mAOD at 16:15 on 30/11/23.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 95 cubic metres per second and is falling. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the next 3 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 30/11/23, or as the situation changes.

In Hambledon, groundwater levels are high but are now slowly falling. Since Friday 24/11/2023, only 17mm of rain has been recorded at Worlds End. The groundwater level at Whitedale Farm peaked on 27/11/2023, around 20cm below the level we expect onset of cellar flooding to a small number of properties on Lower West Street. Since then, the level has fallen by 6cm. The next 5 days are forecast to be predominantly dry with the odd shower. Based on the current forecast, we expect groundwater levels to continue to fall and no cellar flooding is expected during this time. From next week, there is an indication that unsettled weather could affect the south of England. Please remain prepared this winter as groundwater flooding impacts will be possible after the next heavy rainfall event in East Hampshire. We are liaising with the Flood Action Group. We will continue to monitor the forecast and groundwater levels closely, and will re-issue this Flood Alert when we think flooding impacts are possible.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: In Finchdean and Rowlands Castle, groundwater levels are high and rising. Since 25/10/23, 251mm of rain has been recorded in Walderton. This is more than twice the average amount expected during that period. In the last 24 hours, the groundwater level in Finchdean has increased by 30cm. From Sunday 26/11/23, the Idsworth Lavant is expected to be flowing through all villages. From Monday 27/11/23, it is possible pumps which prevent water from entering property may be required. Surface water could flood property during heavier rain events. However, there is a chance groundwater could peak below this impact level. Dry weather is forecast until Sunday 26/11/23. On Monday, up to 25mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. If heavy rain affects the area, the groundwater level will continue to rise throughout next week. If not, then the level is expected to peak next week and water could begin receding. We are liaising with the Flood Action Group. If you use pumps to reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This message will be updated by 17:00 on Thursday 30/11/23.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Ings Beck, Alverthorpe Beck, Balne Beck, Oakenshaw Beck

items.message: River levels on the Ings Beck and Oakenshaw Beck catchment have fallen below levels of concern. We do not expect any significant rain over the next few days. We will continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to the recent rainfall across the area and have risen at our observation borehole in Longacre in the Lambourn Valley. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected within the next few days by flooding from groundwater.

We expect levels to continue to rise over the next few weeks in response to rainfall forecast across the area. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message tomorrow, 30/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

Over the last few days we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Witham area. This means that the River Witham has risen, which will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the River during Wednesday, 29th November onwards. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 13:00 on 30/11/23, or before if the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Beverley and Barmston Drain

items.message: River levels remain high on the Beverley and Barmston Drain and the River Hull, due to recent rainfall. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Showers are expected today, Thursday 30/11/2023. Levels will continue to fluctuate, including the influence of the tide on the River Hull, impacting Beverly Shipyard. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 15:00pm on 30/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  

River and high tide levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  

We continue to monitor the situation.  

Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.
